newsitem.title: UK: S&P sees EMU putting pressure on banking sector.
newsitem.headline: S&P sees EMU putting pressure on banking sector.

text.p: Standard & Poor's said on Monday a successful move to European Economic and Monetary Union (EMU) will put pressure on the commercial position and earnings of many banks and accelerate a trend of consolidation in the sector.
But S&P said EMU will also provide opportunities, particularly in underwriting, trading and brokerage.
"The greater anticipated capital flows in Europe will increase business flow in all these lines," Bugie said.

There is likely to be greater potential to bring lower quality credits to market, and a boost for the mutual funds and asset backed markets. Banks with pan-European networks should particularly be in a position to benefit, the report said.
The rating service predicted an increase in mergers and an acceleration of the consolidation trend that is already occurring in European financial services.
"EMU will open the way for cross-border mergers, with opportunities for economies of scale in selling products over a much wider area.

"Although legal questions remain, these are only likely to delay and not stop the merger trend. Lastly, the "no bail outs' clause in the Maastricht treaty will leave European states with less authority, and less incentive, to support ailing banks in the much bigger single market," S&P said.
